choices.A: The client database entry is different than that of Layer 2 roam. (Instead of copying, it moves the database to the new controller.)
choices.C: The client database entry is different than that of Layer 2 roam because the client database is neither moved nor copied into the new controller.
choices.B: The client database entry is different than that of Layer 2 roam. (Instead of moving, it copies the database to the new controller.)
choices.D: The client database remains in the mobility anchor controller and it is not copied or moved.

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. Client A is roaming from AP1 on WLC1 to AP2 on WLC2. The client roams between two APs registered to two different controllers. The WLAN on the two controllers is on a different subnet. Which scenario explains the client's roaming behavior?

discussion.content: B is the correct one ,in layer 3 roaming , the clients data will be copied instead of moving. moving happen when we have L2

Selected Answer: B
Layer 3 roaming is similar to Layer 2 roaming in that the controllers exchange mobility messages on the client roam. However, instead of moving the client database entry to the new controller, the original controller marks the client with an “Anchor” entry in its own client database. The database entry is copied to the new controller client database and marked with a “Foreign” entry in the new controller. The roam remains transparent to the wireless client, and the client maintains its original IP address

questions.question_text: An engineer working for an enterprise deployed multiple Cisco WLCs. A controller that sits in the R&D division is connected through a firewall and is part of the same mobility group. The engineer must ensure that the mobility tunneling is available through the firewall and test it as R&D engineers roam the production floor within their department. How is this requirement met?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
B is correct Legacy controller platforms that are based on AireOS software prior to release 8.5 transport mobility messages over Ethernet-over-IP (EoIP) tunnels (IP protocol 97) and UDP port 16666.

Selected Answer: B
Provided answer is correct:
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/wireless/controller/8-5/config-guide/b_cg85/mobility_groups.html

choices.D: mping on UDP port 16667 and eping on Protocol 96 between management ports
choices.C: mping on UDP port 16667 and eping on Protocol 97 between management ports
choices.A: mping on UDP port 16666 and eping on Protocol 96 between management ports
choices.B: mping on UDP port 16666 and eping on Protocol 97 between management ports

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Mping is the right answer.

Selected Answer: B
To test whether a mobility control packet can be reached over the management interface, the engineer should issue the mping command over UDP port 16666. This command performs a mobility ping test to validate connectivity between members of a mobility group.

questions.question_text: An engineer is designing a solution where guests terminate on an anchor controller in the DMZ. The engineer is having issues and wants to test connectivity between members of a mobility group. Which command must be issued to test whether a mobility control packet is able to be reached over the management interface?

choices.C: Disable data link encryption on the anchor controller.
choices.A: Run an Inter-Release Controller Mobility compatible software version on the wireless controller.
choices.D: Run an Inter-Release Controller Mobility compatible software version on the anchor controller.
choices.B: Enable control plane encryption on the wireless controller.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
The 5520 needs to run IRC version

Selected Answer: D
To enable IRCM on a Cisco Catalyst 9800, you can configure the controller as an anchor or foreign controller.

Selected Answer: A
IRCM should be enabled on the new WLC , it is not possible that old WLC support IRCM . The old WLC should have AireOS 8.5 to be able to communicate with 9800 and IRCM

questions.question_text: A customer uses a Cisco Catalyst 9800 Series wireless controller to manage all of the APs for a campus network. Secure guest access is required for the guest network. A Cisco 5520 anchor controller is deployed within a DMZ. Which design approach ensures that the mobility tunnel is established successfully between the wireless controller and the anchor controller?

choices.C: Configure ECMP but weigh the cost to be higher to go to the primary.
choices.D: Configure ECMP but weigh the cost to be higher to go to the secondary.
choices.A: Set the Anchor priority for the primary controller to 1.
choices.B: Set the Anchor priority for the secondary controller to 1.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
1 is the highest priority for mobility

A is correct.The question specifically states that Auto-Anchor Mobility is enabled, which means that clients should automatically associate with the primary anchor controller if it's available.
Therefore, setting the primary controller's anchor priority to 1 is the most effective way to ensure that clients connect to the primary controller first and are pushed to the secondary only if necessary.

comments.content: A. This is for mobility, not WLC fall over priority for APs

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
My Option is answer B

questions.question_text: An engineer is working for a manufacturing company that has a centralized deployment model. Guests at headquarters need wireless access for presentations, demonstrations, and sharing of information. The engineer must provide external users with secure guest access by connecting to anchor controllers on the DMZ. Auto-Anchor Mobility has been selected in the mobility group to accomplish it. Both anchors are configured as part of the mobility group for HQ. Which design approach ensures that clients connect to the primary controller first and are pushed to the secondary if the primary fails?
